struct  LEVEL_POSITION
 The level position type is a struct used to store information on each position of a map. More...
struct  LEVEL
 This struct will be the main struct to hold a level. It will contain everything that partains to a certain level. This way we can ensure to keep everything together. Its typedef'ed as a LEVEL type. More...

 This is the number of total layers to create when loading levels.

Definition at line 53 of file LevelManager.h.

Enumeration Type Documentation

enum E_POSITION_TYPE

This enum is used to identify what type of object is contained in a LEVEL_POSITION. It is type defed as POSITION_TYPE.

Enumerator:
POSITION_SPACE  Defines this position as an empty space.
POSITION_ENEMY  Defines this position as an enemy.
POSITION_PLAYER  Defines this position as the player.
POSITION_WALL  Defines this position as a wall.
POSITION_HEALTH  Defines this position as a health pack.
POSITION_SWITCH  Defines this position as a switch.
POSITION_WEAPON  Defines this position as a weapon.

Definition at line 43 of file LevelManager.h.

Function Documentation

LEVEL_POSITION* createLevelPosition ( void *  data,
POSITION_TYPE  type,
char  character 
)

Method for creating a new LEVEL_POSITION.

This is an easy helper method to be used when creating a new LEVEL_POSITION it uses malloc() so that it won't be released when it leaves scope. This means you MUST free it some time later.

Parameters:
data - A pointer to the data to be stored with the new LEVEL_POSITION. It can be used for what ever use you need, usualy for storing a pointer to this particular items other data, such as for an enemy or weapon.
type - The type of object that is in this position, as defined by its POSITION_TYPE.
character - The character to be displayed in this LEVEL_POSITION.
Returns:
A pointer to the newly created LEVEL_POSITION.
See also:
getLevelPosition(), setLevelPosition()

Definition at line 398 of file LevelManager.c.

LEVEL* getCurrentLevel (  ) 

Returns a pointer to the current level that is being used by the game.

This method is used to get a pointer to the current level. Usually, this is the safest method since you won't be tryint to use an outdated level.

Returns:
A pointer to the current level in use.
See also:
setCurrentLevel()

Definition at line 376 of file LevelManager.c.

LEVEL_POSITION* getLevelPosition ( int  layerNumber,
int  x,
int  y 
)

Get a pointer to the struct containing the info for a given level location.

This is the main method used to determine what character is at a certain position.

Parameters:
layerNumber - The layer number you wish to retrieve the LEVEL_POSITION for.
x - The x position of the LEVEL_POSITION to be retrieved.
y - The y position of the LEVEL_POSITION to be retrieved.
Returns:
A pointer to the LEVEL_POSITION located at the given values.
See also:
setLevelPosition()

Definition at line 264 of file LevelManager.c.

int getPositionIndex ( int  layerNumber,
int  x,
int  y 
)

This function calculates the index in the position pointer array that the specified layer x and y value is at.

This function is used to determine the location of a given LEVEL_POSITION based on the layer number, x, and y values. For the most part, this method should never be used directly. The functions getLevelPosition() and setLevelPosition() should provide a sufficient wrapper.

Parameters:
layerNumber - The layer number of the LEVEL_POSITION index to be calculated.
x - The x position of the LEVEL_POSITION index to be calculated.
y - The y position of the LEVEL_POSITION index to be calculated.
Returns:
The index of the LEVEL_POSITION calculated by the input.
See also:
getLevelPosition(), setLevelPosition()

Definition at line 440 of file LevelManager.c.

int isLevelPositionSpace ( int  layerNumber,
int  x,
int  y 
)

Quick convenience method to determine whether a location contains a space.

This method is just a quick way to test to see if a certain level position is a space, since this will likely be needed a lot.

Parameters:
layerNumber - The layer number of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to check.
x - The x position of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to check.
y - The y position of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to check.
Returns:
Returns whether this position contains a space. 1 for yes, 0 for no.
See also:
isLevelPositionWall(), getLevelPosition()

Definition at line 325 of file LevelManager.c.

int isLevelPositionWall ( int  layerNumber,
int  x,
int  y 
)

Quick convenience method returns whether a location contains a wall.

This is just a quick way to determine if a specified position is a wall, since this is likely to be needed a lot.

Parameters:
layerNumber - The layer number of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to check.
x - The x position of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to check.
y - The y position of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to check.
Returns:
Returns whether this position contains a wall. 1 for yes, 0 for no.
See also:
isLevelPositionSpace(), getLevelPosition()

Definition at line 352 of file LevelManager.c.

LEVEL* loadLevel ( char *  fileName  ) 

Load a new level.

This is the main function that should be called in order to load a new level. Loading a new level will set the level to be the current level.

Parameters:
fileName - A pointer to a character array that contains the file name of the map to be loaded.
Returns:
Returns a pointer to the LEVEL that was loaded. It is best to not use this pointer directly, but instead, use getCurrentLevel() to obtain a pointer to the currentLevel (in most cases). This way you can be sure you don't use an invalid pointer later.
See also:
unloadLevel()

Definition at line 64 of file LevelManager.c.

void loadLevelManager (  ) 

This function performs some necessary initialization.

It must be called before the level system can ever be used!

See also:
unloadLevelManager()

Definition at line 23 of file LevelManager.c.

void setCurrentLevel ( LEVEL *  level  ) 

Sets the current level that the game should use.

This is the main way to set the current level to be used. It should be noted that in most cases, calling this method directly is uneccesary, as the loadLevel() function calls setCurrentLevel() itself.

Parameters:
level - A pointer to the LEVEL to be set as the current level.
See also:
getCurrentLevel(), loadLevel()

Definition at line 421 of file LevelManager.c.

void setLevelPosition ( int  layerNumber,
int  x,
int  y,
LEVEL_POSITION *  newLevelPosition 
)

Set the pointer to the LEVEL_POSITION containing the info for the given level location.

This is the main method used to set the LEVEL_POSITION data for the positions in the LEVEL.

Parameters:
layerNumber - The layer number you wish to set the LEVEL_POSITION for.
x - The x value of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to set.
y - The y value of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to set.
newLevelPosition - A pointer to the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to set at the given location.
See also:
getLevelPosition()

Definition at line 295 of file LevelManager.c.

void unloadLevel ( LEVEL  level  ) 

This function is called to unload a level.

The current level should always be unloaded before a new one is loaded, to ensure no memory leeks are created.

Parameters:
level - A pointer to the level to be unloaded.
See also:
loadLevel()

Definition at line 250 of file LevelManager.c.

void unloadLevelManager (  ) 

This function performs the necessary clean up for the level manager.

It is important that this be called before the program exits. However, the level manager must NOT be used once this has been called. If it is, in any way, we could end up with invalid pointers. All level's should be unloaded also before this is called.

See also:
loadLevelManager()

Definition at line 41 of file LevelManager.c.
